user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_tell:
```c
lfs_soff_t lfs_dir_tell(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_tell(%p, %p)", (void*)lfs, (void*)dir);

    lfs_soff_t res = lfs_dir_tell_(lfs, dir);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_tell -> %"PRId32, res);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_dir_tell:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
typedef int32_t  lfs_soff_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment in lfs_dir_tell modifies either function parameter itself. There are no assignments to 'lfs' or 'dir', and the only uses are: - reading lfs->cfg in LFS_LOCK/LFS_UNLOCK (the macros expand to ((void)cfg,0) / ((void)cfg) and do not modify the pointer), - casting the pointers for tracing (casts do not modify the parameters), and - passing the pointers to lfs_dir_tell_ (calling another function with these pointers is allowed; modifying the object pointed-to is permitted, but modifying the pointer variable in this function would violate the rule). Therefore there are no fragments here that need investigation for Rule 17.8. If investigation of related code is desired, only the body of lfs_dir_tell_ would be relevant (to check whether it modifies its own parameters), but that is outside the provided function and not required to demonstrate a violation in this function.
